metadata.title: Complete Data Engineer’s Vocabulary | by Kovid Rathee | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Update— incorporated suggestions by George Slokoski, Axel Furlan and Nisha Baxi. Last updated — 15th July 2020 Over the years, I have used many of these technologies working with databases, data…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Over the years, I have used many of these technologies

all_paragraphs: Update— incorporated suggestions by George Slokoski, Axel Furlan and Nisha Baxi. Last updated — 15th July 2020

Over the years, I have used many of these technologies working with databases, data warehouses, building data pipelines, using ETL frameworks and processing big data — even working on spreadsheets. All of these technologies require weeks of study and probably months of practice to perfect.

I thought it would be really interesting to summarize or introduce a technology within 10 words. I have listed ~150 concepts and technologies here along with their ≤ 10 word explainations. Obviously, this list is limited by my knowledge of the field but I think it’s a good list of things to know if you want to be a data engineer in 2020.
Almost all of the pointers have a link to the homepage of the technology or an interesting blogpost about it. Use the links embedded in the names. Here we go.
ACID — transaction enforcement properties of a database; atomicity, consistency, isolation, durability
Atomicity —if one step (of multi-step task) fails, whole transaction fails
Avro — compact, row-oriented, JSON-based, data format
Azkaban — LinkedIn’s batch scheduler for Hadoop jobs
Airflow — Airbnb’s programmable DAG based job scheduler. Very popular Apache project
Analytic Function — aggregate functions that operate on a group of rows
Big Data — large enough that it can’t be processed by traditional systems
BI — technologies, processes to get the best information out of data
Batch Processing — doing many tasks in one go, i.e., loading 100M records
BigQuery — Google’s serverless datawarehose that competes with Redshift and Azure DW
BigTable — Petabyte scale NoSQL database by Google
Cassandra — distributed NoSQL database popular for columnar storage capabilities
CTE — a result set cache that can be referred by name in SQL
Caching — temporarily storing data for anticipated future reuse
Column Oriented Database — storage where column values are stored contiguously on disk
Cloud Composer — Google’s Airflow implementation
Cube — multi-dimensional data; term used in data warehousing
Catalog — organization of metadata with management and search capability
Cloud Functions — Google’s serverless compute option like AWS Lambda
DynamoDB — Petabyte scale key-value, document database by AWS
Druid — distributed columnar data store
Drill — SQL for non-relational, JSON, nested data in Hadoop, NoSQL databases
Dremel — Google’s large-scale proprietary interactive query engine
Distributed Processing — split tasks and process on different compute units for faster results
DataFrame — relational database table like contruct in programming languages
DW — single source of truth datastore for business reporting and analysis
DAG — dependency graph with no circular dependencies — using in orchestration engines
Dataflow — Google’s managed data pipelining solution
Dataprep — Google’s data preparation (cleaning, wrangling etc.) solution
Dataproc — Google’s fully managed Spark/Hadoop offering
Dashboard — a visualization setup for tracking performance, KPIs etc.
Data Dictionary — in-depth metadata revealing structure and uses of a data source
Data Downtime— times when data is partial, erroneous, missing or otherwise inaccurate
Data Mart — subset of data warehouse, usually for a specific business function
Dimension — descriptor or categorizer of data
DBRE — a branch of SRE pertaining to database reliability
Data Custodian — the owner of all things data
DataVault — data warehouse design methodology
DBT — SQL based data pipelining and workflow solution
Docker —OS level virtualization forming containers
Elasticsearch — the de facto fulltext search engine
Enrichment — process of enriching data with more data
ETL — extract from source, transform, load into destination
ELT — extract from source, load into destination and transform
ER Diagram — a diagram visualizing relationships between database entities
ELK — the de facto open-source application log processing & monitoring solution
Flume — large scale data pipelining for events stream data
Flink — distributed processing engine for data streams
Flat File — usually a text or a binary file
Fact — a measurement of a business process, e.g., total sales
Failover — moving from a failed machine to a working machine
Glue — large scale serverless ETL, data pipelining solution from AWS
Golden Record — single source of truth
Hadoop — big data processing framework comprising of MapReduce, YARN and HDFS
Hive — SQL-like query engine to access data stored on Hadoop ecosystem
HBase — non-relational distributed database that runs on top of Hadoop
HDFS — Hadoop’s distributed file system
Ingestion — inserting data into a system, i.e., data ingestion
Integration — bring together multiple sources of data
In-memory — in-memory storage, in-memory computation, i.e. not on disk
JSON —the de facto data transportation format over the internet
Kafka — LinkedIn’s distributed streaming framework
Kinesis — AWS’s managed Kafkaesque streaming service
Kibana — monitoring & visualization solution in the ETK stack
Key-Value Store — data is stored in a dictionary or hash-table like structure
Kubernetes — Google’s container orchestration service, lovingly called K8s
Looker — Google’s latest browser based BI tool acquisition
Luigi — Spotify’s job orchestration engine
Lake — raw store of all the data of the business
Lambda —AWS’s FaaS offering — very popular
Logstash — log analysis solution in the ELK stack
Lineage — journey from raw to processed and processed to final
MySQL — very popular open source relational database
MongoDB — very popular open source NoSQL database
MariaDB — MySQL’s fork maintained by the original MySQL team
MapReduce — a programming model for distributed computing; bedrock of Hadoop
MLlib — Spark’s machine learning library
Metabase — popular open source data visualization solution
MDM — management of critical business data to a single point
MDX — MS SQL Server’s propreitary feature for OLAP quer
Materialized View — query resultset stored as a database object persisted on disk
MPP — parallel coordinated computing by large number of processors
NoSQL — group of database technologies which are more than relational databases
Neo4j — the de facto graph-oriented database
Nomad — scheduling solution from HashiCorp
Near Real Time — almost real time with delays only from physical constraints
Normalization — organizational concept in relational databases
ORC — high performance open-source columnar storage format
Oozie — DAG based workflow scheduler for Hadoop jobs
OLAP — analytical processing, without transactions, usually for data warehouses
OLTP — transactional processing, with ACID properties
ODS — operational data store, similar in purpose to a DW
PostgreSQL — programmers’ favorite open-source database
PostGIS — extention for geospatial data support in PostgreSQL
Percona — offers forks of MySQL, MongoDB etc. with advanced features
Parquet — the de facto open-source columnar storage format
PySpark — Python wrapper over Spark
Presto — Facebook’s open-source distributed query engine
Plotly — the de facto visualization library for data scientists & ML engineers
Pipeline — series of processes & computations to transform & transport data
Partitioning — splitting a table into multiple parts to query less data
Pandas — the de facto data processing library in Python
Pub/Sub — publish, subscribe model for events stream processing
Python — the de facto language for doing data engineering, data science
Query Engine — the piece of software that executes queries against a dataset
Query Optimizer — database component that optimizer & rewrites SQL queries
Query Plan — the execution plan using which query engine executes queries
Query Cost — the cost of running a query in terms of processing
RDS — managed relational database service from AWS
RBAC — Systems access based on job role and clearance of someone
RabbitMQ — the de facto message broker.
Redshift — most popular managed, petabyte scale data warehousing solution
Redis — popular caching solution for applications
Redash — great visualization tool for basic reporting and analysis
Replication — making redundant copies of databases for failover, load distribution
RDD — main processing construct within Spark. Know more here.
Row Oriented Database — where data record/row level data is stored contiguously on disk/memory
S3 — most popular cloud storage service, offered by AWS
SQL — the language that data speaks
Sqoop — bulk data trasfers to and from Hadoop
Spark — the de facto big data processing engine with SQL support
Storm — open-source, realtime computation engine
Superset — Airbnb’s web based data visualization & BI tool, incubating at Apache
Sharding — splitting and storing a database on multiple machines
Storage Engine — data storage operating layer of a database
Star Schema — popular data warehouse design methodology. Read more here
Snowflake Schema — popular data warehouse design methodology. Read more here
SCD — data category values that change slowly with time, e.g., city of residence
Single Source of Truth — data source considered to reflect the truth about the business
Structured Data — data following some pre-defined schema or format
Semi-structured Data — doesn’t follow formal structure but still contains other markers
SRE — Google’s reimagining of a DevOps, reliability engineer
Terraform — the de facto Infrastructure-as-code product by HashiCorp
Thrift — framework to support cross language development
Unstructured Data — data without a schema or a pre-defined structure
Vertica — reasonably popular data warehousing so
VoltDB — in-memory database with serialized transactions
View —unpersisted database object represented by a SQL query
Wrangling — cleaning the data, making it ready for analysis
Window Function — SQL calculation across multiple rows in relation to current row
Nothing here. Or maybe there is.
YARN — resource manager for Hadoop ecosystem (used for MapReduce and Spark)
Zookeeper — centralized configuration management service
I write about tech, Indian classical music, literature, and the workplace among other things. 1x engineer on weekdays. https://kovidrathee.medium.com/membership
